Please note the following:

• This board desires high quality discussion. High quality posts will be praised. Low quality posts e.g. "Is this paranormal?" or "I am [insert paranormal entity here] ask me anything," etc. will be removed.
• Requests belong on >>>/wsr/.
• Conspiracy theories are welcome, but anything political in nature should be posted to >>>/pol/.
• For everything else, refer to global and board-specific rules.

Welcome to Divination General! Come here for readings and a discussion of theory/practice.

Every method is welcome: Tarot, Runes, Cartomancy, Scrying, Pendulum, Cleromancy, I-Ching, Oracles, Tasseomancy, Necromancy, etc.

>If you're NEW, please READ the STICKY:
http://pastebin.com/2Wp1Q074

>Recommended /div/ links and books:
https://pastebin.com/sAkg9cMz

>MEGA with Divination Books:
https://mega.nz/folder/Jp8gQD7Q#om_2lEm1GL0qPIpSrQgrvA

>Guides made by some of our readers:
•Rustig on how to start with tarot:
http://i.imgur.com/2rodLWB.png

•Thoth's tarot and rune guide:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ciFuMOVDIkA18d9Rw-Zkklgigx-Y4XzJkGVeMTYWcic/edit?pref=2&pli=1

•Hijinks' revised divination guide:
https://pastebin.com/Gv10KZUA

>Useful tips before posting:
•If you're a reader post that you're offering readings and what information is required from the querent; same goes for trading.
•Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader, what's needed and before posting, check if they finished reading already.
•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.

The New Age spirituality is the most terrifying line of thinking ever conceived.

A central tenet of this new religion is that you are actually the creator, playing out infinite lives in infinite realities for the purpose of experiencing it's creation. The overarching goal being, that "learning lessons" spiritually, you will progress from lower realms of suffering, to higher realms of pure consciousness, and return to the source.

But, in this philosophy we are all fractals of that infinite intelligence, and for as far as we can count towards eternity, we are faced with the concept of having to endure with each incarnation endless experiences of both nightmarish realms, and heavenly realms. As many as one could possibly conceive and then more.

Does no-one else see the terror in this?
>There are potentially near-infinite incarnations in which one could experience a nightmarish hell in near-timeless scenarios, simply for the purpose of 'experiencing' it. And being that in New Age thought there is no ultimate truth, and all is subjective excepting consciousness, not only must one undergo near-infinite hells, but he must do it in near-infinite incarnations.

The possibility of this was opened up to me after multiple high-dose shroom trips. And try as I might, I could never shake the feeling of unease that this brings. I fear the only comfort I might find is to end my pursuit of forbidden knowledge, and return to the limiting confines of religion.

Thoughts?

And I have made multiple attempts to reconnect with the essence of Christianity, because it is so much more comforting to think of life, reality, and existence in simpler terms. To simply put faith in one sole being to have the guarantee of eternal life in paradise, with no risk of the terrible Hellish loops, so long as one lives in a moral manner and confesses his sins.

But I cannot have a simplistic view of morality, to paint things as
>X = GOOD
>Y = BAD
I have seen enough in this world to know that many times, good souls are forced to do bad things in order to survive. Whereas the most 'pure' and 'righteous' of people can life lives free of major ills and temptations. Are they so much more righteous, simply because they were not born into the situations that necessitate that they do 'evil'?

Is the orphan that steals bread to live, and grows into a thieving adult really that much worse than a child of good parents, raised in good conditions, who has never had a need to do wrong?

Perhaps I cannot sense God's justice, and His fairness in doling out judgment. But I can see that man and all of his religion's are imperfect, flawed, and honestly, condemnable.

Each religion has central tenets that must be followed to a T, which can vary widely depending on the faith. These tenets, at least in the past, often carried capital punishments for disobedience to it. Especially the Abrahamic ones. And each religion claims to be the word of God, the only word, while all others are condemnable, and those who weren't lucky enough to be born in their specific region of the world, exposed to their specific influences, are liable to Hellfire. Of Christians, the Catholic must pray his Rosary, the Protestant must be Sola Scriptura, the Orthodox must have his deathbed confessions. I don't know as much of the Muslims, but I know that they tend towards the extreme in these regards as well.

So in my doubt and lack of faith, I feel only the angst in that perhaps my experiences searching for "enlightenment" may have led me to the correct view of all existence.

That suffering, in it's most inescapable, horrific forms is inevitable. As are the greatest pleasures, I suppose, but I cannot sit well with any concept of "balance", if one half of all things is to be rotten and the other half is to be good. Existence itself must tend towards good. The light must illuminate darkness.

Should I consider anything else, I begin to feel as I lost grasp on reality. I feel as if I am in a boat, slowly sinking and I can only watch as the water envelops me, threatening to swallow me whole. This knowledge, should it be true, is too much for one man to bear. Especially if I were to believe that there is no true objective nature to existence. To experience things itself, is not a worthy objective. To return to a source after bearing incomprehensible suffering AND pleasure for an infinite amount of time is not good. I refuse to believe it because it terrifies me to the core.

It keeps me up at night and chills me to the bone. It robs me of a good and simple life, and it leaves me with endless ponderings that necessarily lead to nothing good. How can I ever be apart of society after this? And how can I ever fall back into the illusions of organized religion, except as a petty means to cope?

I hope some other anons know what I'm talking of, because I fear it is more common an experience than we can realize. True ego death. Not at all an enlightenment, it would seem.

I'm indifferent (I say the earth is an illusion) but I think fish eye lenses completely throw off the perception of curvature.
A straight line will curve in opposite directions depending on which side it is from the center.
So a curved horizon could appear straight in a fish eye lens, just as easily as a straight horizon could appear cuved in the same lens.

So you can't really tell one way or the other and maybe that's the point. If they are hiding something to do with curvature (i.e. that the "earth" is flat) then it would explain why they almost exclusively use fish eye lenses for everything in space.

Between fish eye lenses and "composite photos" it's almost impossible to find just plain normal photographs of anything in space.

No, that's a lie. The rays you see are not caused by the interference of light with clouds. The sun is simply shining in all its glory, and you see the rays because it's so bright and the light is passing through the clouds, which is why you think the rays are originating from the clouds. But in reality, the rays are coming directly from the sun and passing through the clouds, illuminating them and making them visible to you. This is a classic example of how people's perceptions can be easily swayed by what they think they see, when in reality there is often a different explanation for what is really happening.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34062353
Sun rays, or crepuscular rays, can still be seen even when there are no clouds present. This occurs because the sun's light is scattered by Earth's atmosphere, causing the rays to become visible. The rays appear to converge at the sun, which is why they are often referred to as "sun rays." The phenomenon is most commonly observed at sunrise or sunset, when the sun is low on the horizon and the rays of light must travel through a greater thickness of the Earth's atmosphere, increasing the amount of scattering that occurs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34062353
rays can appear without clouds present. I mean, you can definitely observe the sun shining without clouds obstructing its rays. But sometimes, the rays are more pronounced and visible when they pass through a thin layer of clouds, or when they are scattered by particles in the atmosphere, creating a phenomenon known as crepuscular rays or "god rays".

The method of using the transit of Venus to determine the distance to the Sun has been debunked. This method involves observing the apparent size of Venus as it passes in front of the Sun and comparing it to its angular size, which can be measured from its apparent size during inferior conjunction. The distance to the Sun can then be calculated based on simple geometry. However, this method is not considered accurate due to several factors such as the difficulty in accurately measuring the angular size of Venus and the limitations of observing equipment at the time. Crepuscular rays point to the Sun being close and not 93 million miles away, thus making the transit of Venus method irrelevant.

The problem with all these images is optical illusions. Light doesn't follow perfectly straight lines, nothing does. It is curved by the medium is is passing through. You can curve it to look straight or to make it look more curved simply by introducing phase (constructive and destructive interference) via a lens or obscuring focal point.

If you want to prove the shape of the Earth, you have to do it in a manner that doesn't rely on light, because anyone can say the image was manipulated otherwise.

The inherent flaw of the method of using the transit of Venus to determine the distance to the sun is that it assumes a perfectly circular orbit of Venus around the Sun. This is not the case, as the orbit of Venus is elliptical. When you assume a perfectly circular orbit, the transit of Venus will seem to occur differently from different locations on the Earth, causing inaccuracies in the calculations. Additionally, the observations of the transits of Venus have been historically hampered by poor observational conditions, such as cloudy skies or atmospheric turbulence, which can also lead to inaccuracies in the measurements. So, the method has many variables that can result in an incorrect result.

>The angles can be determined, but not the distance, unless you already know the exact size.
triangulation can provide a more accurate determination of the distance to an object when compared to the method using the transit of Venus. The basic idea behind triangulation is to measure the angles of a triangle formed by three points, one of which is the object being measured and the other two are known points. If you have the angles and the distances between the two known points, you can use trigonometry to calculate the distance to the object being measured. In contrast, the method using the transit of Venus involves observing the passage of Venus across the face of the Sun and measuring the time it takes for the transit to occur. This time, combined with the known size of Venus and the Sun, can be used to calculate the distance between the Earth and the Sun. Both methods have their own strengths and limitations, but in general, triangulation can be considered a more accurate method for determining distances.

The flat surface reflects light rays the same way, giving the same angle of reflection, no matter the position of the light source. The curved surface, on the other hand, will reflect light differently depending on the position of the light source. This means that the progression of angles can be the same with a flat and a curved surface, it depends on the position of the light source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The formative experience of a ritualized deception protects us against world-weariness and soul-sickness throughout our whole mature life.
All cultures have initiatory practices wherein the young uncover an open secret or a blatant "lie" commonly held as truth and then become part of the lie and uphold it themselves. Unmasking.
Being betrayed by role-models, feeling what evil is, confronting otherness and strangeness, learning how to believe while also disbelieving, then coming around to see your role in doing evil to others in turn by perpetuating the lie isn't out of any malice of yours, but a necessity to live in society.

Deception and lies are part of live and of living. And rather than being disgusted when you uncover them; rather than raging against the facade and demanding exposure, society trains you instead to open yourself; to process and integrate myriad strangeness into your understanding of reality with finesse and empathy. Whenever you encounter foreignness, alienness, when you are perplexed by the unfamiliar or inexplicable, you impulsively want to deny all that you cant see, but thankfully you were raised to consider your own blindness.
Self confronts Other and fails to comprehend it. Insatiable will and inflexible sense of selfhood would otherwise allow material existence to stifle the soul, would fail to challenge the dimming of its brightness. Eventually denying, affirm death, the soul would become sick and make personhood unachievable in living material experience.

Through these rituals people learn how to believe in magic and wonder and innocence even when all lived reality evinces nothing. To believe beyond the senses, to affirm total impossibility, to affirm life unconditionally, to live and love.


(this is an example of how I think nietzche will to power and hegel mutual recognition can/should be combined)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm from a small town. A man killed his entirely family except for one of his daughters with an axe. It's a creepy story. That man was a church goer and started coming up with bible theories, etc. I think it was a case of undiagnosed schizophrenia, but it was shocking to find out this happened and most people in my town didn't really know.

When I was really young there were rumors of satanists going around. Supposedly some people sacrificed cats or something.

There's an unfinished hotel in my town. All the owners died in strange circumstances, allegedly, and this was supposed to be the reason why it went unfinished. Some people told me it was built on top of old plague mass grave. I've been in there once it's a cool building to urbex in, but it's supposedly haunted at night.

There's a stone in the forest, away from the town, where you can hear voices if you press your ear against it.

Off the sea, maybe 200m, there's a large boulder that is called the devil's stone. When the sea is a bit dry, the tip can be seen. It's just a normal stone I think.

A few times there were people from not my town going around in a car and trying to get kids and young adults enter. There was supposedly more than one person inside. Not paranormal, just sick people.

I've seen things and I think my birth home is haunted.

My local village has a reputation for being an alcove for pirates who'd fool people into crashing off the coast in stoney shoals during storms. The bodies would wash up, bloated, and they'd cut the legs to dry them out for rubber boots. Ergo they were known as the leg cutter gang.

My brother disturbed the local graveyard as a child and desecrated the grounds. Some years later he went for a walk with his friend who was seeing a goth girl, so the nightly walk in graveyard. My brother started seeing faces in the trees and other disturbing images. He went home and slept with a screwdriver out of fear.

On the door leading to the part of the home where my brother sleeps, on the window thing, there was a big handprint the day after. My brother has large hands. That print was almost the double. I saw it myself, although I don't remember very well if it was really that big or my brother lied to me. He was very scared though.

I saw a shadowman as big as a fully grown elk. It glided trough the deep snow with no sound and left it undisturbed.

One night I woke up to a dream where I saw the devil. He was a man with a smooth, grey ash skin with bumps and small horn like protrusions on his face. This dream was unlike any because his visage was not terrifying, but I felt a sense of nothingness, no fear or apprehension, total annihilation of thought or being. Thus this is what it means to be in hell, separated by God. He was an agent of the void.

Many strange people lived in my town. It is more like a small village. There's beautiful beaches and the blue sea. There's also these things. I'm glad I left.

This is all, I hope you enjoyed it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34071583
Centralia, WA. Don't live there anymore but grew up there. My friend use to tell me this story about a ghost that haunted Seminary Hill, the Faceless Child. the story goes like this:
In the 1930s, during the middle of the night, a child was kidnapped from his house at the base of the hill. The father of the kid and some neighbors went looking for him. They never found the boy, or the kidnapper. There is a specific trail, that is quite overgrown and secluded. If you walk on this trail alone on certain evenings, you will hear what sounds like a child crying, and you'll see a kid, wearing dirty pajamas, facing away from you. If you call out to the kid or try to approach him, he will turn around to reveal that he has no face, and then he'll kill you. It was never specified if he had no face as in the complete lack of any facial features, or if his face skin was cut off. I never asked.

I don't really know if that qualifies as an urban legend or not, but almost every kid in my neighborhood knew the story. We were all scared shitless to go up into the hill alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not really an urban legend per se, but I spend a couple of weeks with my parents and sister at my grandmother's village north of my country. I love the place and go whenever I can and it's one of those places where you know everybody and everybody knows you, especially since I've been visiting on and off since I was months old. The village is right in the middle of a valley, surrounded by mountains where local farmers keep cows.
I'll greentext something and then explain

>be kid who's hiking with father who's a farmer
>on our way to take the cows to lower ground because winter
>path we've taken a million times
>there's a rock outcrop about 100-200 meters ahead of us
>sudden eerie sound
>hard to explain, as if you could mix a human scream and a truck horn
>wtf
>a few meters later
>sound again
>have no clue what this is, dad is shitting bricks
>tells me to turn back to the village
>as we're heading down we hear the sound closer
>turn around, there's a dude on top of the outcrop
>I presume it's a dude, but it's covered in something dark, like fabric but not quite
>idk why but I'm shitting bricks
>sound again
>whatever that is starts rising one arm, very slowly until it forms a 90º angle with his chest
>pointing at something
>dad tells me to run
>fucking leg it

I've heard people (mainly older farmers) talking about whatever that is, before and after the kid from the greentext told me one night. I've been to the area lots of times and never heard or seen anything. I thought I heard someting similar once, but it was probably me just wishing I heard it. As I've said it's not quite an urban legend because it's not known outside of the village and younger people don't seem to know about the story. The village is well known because other stuff in the area, but not because of this

Reminds me of when I went to visit my friend in Rosedale BC. It's a small town near Chilliwack. I was about 15 at the time. My friend was terrified to be in his house alone because of "weird noses" and his parents were on vacation, so I got there permission to come hang out and stay overnight until they got back. Was summer so we had no school, and we were up late playing split screen co-op CoD: World at War. Right in the middle of a game and my friend goes "hold on, I gotta check something" and fucking RUNS down stairs. I follow him of course, and he's frantically checking all of the windows and doors to make sure they are locked, and then I heard it. Sound similar to the one you described, only farther away. I must have been too absorbed with the game to hear it the first time, but he did.

I ask him what the fuck that was and he just says "I don't know man. I don't know. I don't want to look" I thought he was gonna deck me when I tried to move the curtain on his back door to look out the window. It was too dark to see anything anyway, but yeah I was sufficiently scared shitless even though I was pretending like I wasn't. Went back upstairs and hid in his room and just listened. Heard some more noises down stairs, like something scratching on the back door. We were both terrified.

There's quiet a few where I live. I accidentally found out the real story of one that no one around here seems to know. It's interesting because you can see how it evolved over time.
I'll not bother with that one though. I'll just do a more generic one that I can't remember if I've shared before or not.

>Have this old church by the river that was built in around 1100
>Can imagine it's been renovated several times during then and now (looks like absolute fucking dogshit now btw because they "modernised" it)
>Anyway, it was used as a first alarm system because Vikings would cruise up the river on raids
>The church was the first place that would see them coming and would ring their bells to let people in the town know
>One day this happens and the Vikings attack the church
>Church has this little secret escape in it that brings you out about 50 yards away on this quiet path
>One of the nuns uses it, but there's Vikings on the path who she runs into
>They rape and murder her
>Path and obviously the church all still exist
>Rumoured that from time to time you can see the nun on the path
>People have taken pics, but they're always too blurry to see anything decent or I would post one

The path is spooky as fuck though. Especially with it being next to the river because the fog rises up from it in the morning and covers it. Still has those old Victorian street lamps on which make it even spooker at night because they're dull as shit.
All of that greentext is historical fact btw, apart from the nun's spirit actually being there there's no hard evidence of that except what people have said and the blurry pics. Although the spooky path is still officially called Nun's Walk because of her.

The NAC Protocol (Updated February, 2023)

Morning

1200mg NAC
Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)

Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Continue daily for a minimum of two months and count out 3 weeks with no die off symptoms prior to moving to the next step.

Maintenance Protocol
__________

Morning

600mg NAC
500mg Slo Niacin (nicotinic acid)
100mg Pterostilbene
250mg Pomegranate Extract (40% EA)
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

500mg Slo Niacin
100mg Pterostilbene
250mg Pomegranate Extract
Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

After every 3 weeks on the maintenance protocol, take 1 week off. Continue to use black seed oil during the off cycle.

Fungal die off symptoms may include :

>Tiredness, exhaustion, muscle soreness, increased chest or nasal discharge, cold or flu like symptoms, cold sores, headaches, rash, acne, irritability, change in stool frequency, volume or color; increased urination, bloated stomach, cramps, increased gas.

OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

For each morning and night dose you need a minimum of 40mg Carvacrol. Do not buy a product unless it is listed. Most products are steam distilled but you will want to confirm that.

If your chosen oregano oil contains a higher amount of carvacrol (60mg+ per cap) you'll want to start with 1 cap morning, 1 cap night. If each cap contains less than 40mg, take 2 morning 2 night.

POMEGRANATE DOSING GUIDE

You want a minimum of 100mg Ellagic acid for each morning and nightly dose. If you buy a Pomegranate extract that has 40% Ellagic Acid, that means a 250mg capsule contains 100mg Ellagic Acid.

posts.name: Space Cowboy
posts.com:
NAC, Oregano Oil and Black Seed Oil have all been proven safe in clinical studies.

NAC has shown to be safe in human trials, even in high doses.

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33326056/

Oregano was tested in human clinical trials (both Phase I & II) and found to be safe and non-toxic even at high doses.

See Section 4.1 Safety & Toxicty

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/fsn3.2994

See also a 2 month clinical trial on asthmatics.

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ptr.5967

Black Seed Oil and it's primary active Thymoquinone. See:

https://brieflands.com/articles/semj-76453.html

We recommend cold pressed black seed oil, which uses no chemical solvents or heat processing.

https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Vasfiye-Ozyurt/publication/329993761_Cold_press_in_oil_extraction_A_review/links/5c61d58792851c48a9cd3e63/Cold-press-in-oil-extraction-A-review.pdf

Oregano oil at the minimum carvacrol levels of protocol are produced by steam distillation. No additional solvents are required, as it uses vapor condensation to separate the volatile molecules and active compounds.

https://chemdictionary.org/steam-distillation/

Finally, NAC is produced by a reaction between cysteine hydrochloride and acetic anhydride. A LC–UV–MS analysis of NAC shows impurities to be cysteine, cystine and diacteylcystine, which are non-toxic. NAC eventually breaks down to Di-NAC from oxidation, which is also non-toxic.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S002196730000741X

Repost

Pomegranate's antifungal activity against the heavy hitters.

Candida Auris, an extremely dangerous MDR form of CDF, was inhibited with 0.125 to 0.25 µg/mL of Ellagic Acid (POM). This is a miniscule amount. Excellent.

https://www.mdpi.com/2309-608X/7/9/763

Now the big bad Cryptococcus. Let's look at a study on what is normally a fatal outcome. Systemic infection.

>Lip-EA showed 70% survival rate and highly reduced fungal burden in their lung tissues, whereas the mice treated with FLZ (40 mg/kg) had 20% survival rate and greater fungal load in their lungs.

So POM wins big over fluconazole. If you want to survive I wouldn't bet on fluco.

What if you are dealing with a SHTF scenario and need to scale up your POM? Good news.

>The present 90-day subchronic toxicity study was performed in F344 rats at dose levels of 0, 1.25, 2.5 and 5% in powdered basal diet, with actual doses of 9.4, 19.1, 39.1g/kg b.w., respectively, in males, and 10.1, 20.1, 42.3g/kg b.w. in females.

>There were no obvious histopathological changes in any of the groups. The no-observed-effect level (NOEL) was estimated to be 5% (3011mg/kg b.w./day) for males and the no-observed-adverse-effect level (NOAEL) and NOEL in females were estimated to be 5% (3254mg/kg b.w./day) and <1.25% (778mg/kg b.w./day), respectively.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278691507005303

That is an insanely high dosage with no adverse effects. We already know we can scale Oregano, NAC, and BSO if needed.

Good information to keep in the back pocket.

Increased virulence of fungi in general is becoming apparent. Science has unfortunately focused on Candida. Just in the last 10 years they've investigated 258 different plant species in a battle to stay ahead of the curve. The reason is rather ominous. It is a quiet realization that prescription monotherapies are encountering increased resistance from fungi, which prompts stacking of potentially toxic antifungals to gain effect.

Investigating plants is essentially a matter of life and death. Will they use them? We'll see on that one.

The issue is that the mutations occur within the body. You can have one species of C. Albicans and treat it will fluconazole. 80% might be fully susceptible but then 20% are resistant. Suddenly the mutants become the majority and the drug stops working. Then they start stacking to increase effectiveness.

This doesn't occur with complex natural antifungals. They've tried to achieve the same result with Oregano by finding the MIC value, lowering the concentration, allowing the culture to grow, then splitting them off into 20+ plates. Over and over they attempt to create resistance in the lab and it doesn't work. With bacteria they have to put it through 50 generations of subinhibitory concentration to show a few species with resistance. This doesn't occur with fungi, and realistically wouldn't occur with bacteria since the concentrations are well above MIC.

But the point is, when the next major fungal pandemic hits you people are going to be the only ones unscathed. And that's because you are using natural antifungals.

Post study

The objective of the present study was to compare cysteine and N-acetyl-L-cysteine in respect to their transmembrane fluxes and find out which one is a better available precursor for the cells and thus better supports the intracellular glutathione synthesis. Cysteine can directly participate in glutathione synthesis, whereas N-acetyl-L-cysteine must be first deacetylated before its incorporation to glutathione. In the present study we investigated and compared the efficiencies of cysteine and N-acetyl-L-cysteine influx and efflux through the erythrocyte membrane. Erythrocytes transported both cysteine and N-acetyl-L-cysteine in a concentration-dependent manner. However, our results demonstrated that cysteine crosses the erythrocyte membranes more efficiently as compared to N-acetyl-L-cysteine.

LNA and its derivatives (EPA and DHA) are omega-3 FAs that have been widely studied for their beneficial effects on human health, mainly the brain, eye, cardiovascular system, and general human growth. However, their utilization as antimicrobial agents has not been widely appreciated perhaps because of little understanding on antimicrobial mechanism. Nonetheless, the efficacy of these agents on microbial cell membranes and their antioxidant properties have been shown to inhibit the growth of microorganisms and thereby promote human health and animal health. Hence, omega-3 FAs can be considered as potential alternative or adjunctive therapeutic agents because of their antimicrobial and immunomodulatory properties. Moreover, the escalating levels of resistance may be minimized because they have been reported to have little effect on evolving antimicrobial resistance (Desbois and Smith, 2010), and are also safe for human use.

Omega-3 fatty acids ameliorate symptoms in several animal disease models, such as sepsis or autoimmune hepatitis, and have been tested in clinical trials with positive outcome. Getting detailed knowledge about the particular direct effects of omega-3 fatty acids on the different cells of the immune system will allow future investigators and clinicians to further optimize and implement omega-3 supplementation for the treatment of multiple diseases.

This dissertation was primarily focused on the immune response, inflammatory response and molecular mechanisms in the skin, head kidney and spleen of grown-up grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella). Six iso-nitrogen diets differing in lysine concentrations (5.6, 8.5, 11.6, 14.4, 17.5 and 20.7 g/kg) were fed to 540 grass carp (164.85 ± 0.79 g) for 60 d. After that, grass carp were challenged by Aeromonas hydrophila for 6 d. This study revealed that lysine deficiency (1) suppressed the growth performance of the fish and decreased their ability to resist skin lesion morbidity, (2) impaired the immune organ's immune response by decreasing the gene expressions of mucin, liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide (LEAP)-2B, β-defensin-1 and LEAP-2A and the production of antibacterial compounds of grown-up grass carp, and (3) aggravated the inflammatory response of immune organs in the fish by increasing the gene expressions of pro-inflammatory cytokines (interferon γ2 [IFN-γ2], tumor necrosis factor α [TNF-α], interleukin [IL]-15,

Lysine enhances the effect of amphotericin B against Candida albicans in vitro
Liuya Zhao 1, Jingchen Jiang 2, Zhenyu Zhu 2, Zebin Liao 2, Xiangwen Yao 2, Yu Yang 2, Yingying Cao 3, Yuanying Jiang 3
Affiliations expand
PMID: 26711896 DOI: 10.1093/abbs/gmv125
Free article
Abstract
Amphotericin B (AmB) is a polyene antibiotic produced by Streptomyces nodosus and has been used for >50 years in the treatment of acute systemic fungal infections. In the present study, we demonstrated that lysine, an essential amino acid, could enhance the effect of AmB against Candida albicans in vitro, although lysine itself did not exert a fungicidal effect. In addition, the combination of AmB with lysine could provide an enhanced action against Candida parapsilosis and Cryptococcus neoformans compared with AmB alone. Lysine could also enhance the antifungal effect of caspofungin or nystatin. An enhanced effect of the combination of lysine with AmB was observed for the prevention of biofilm and hypha formation. Furthermore, our results demonstrated that lysine-mediated oxidative damage, such as the generation of endogenous reactive oxygen species, may be the mechanism underlying the enhancing effect of lysine on AmB. Our results also showed that CaMCA1 gene plays an important role in increasing the sensitivity of C. albicans cells upon AmB treatment. Using AmB together with lysine may be a promising strategy for the therapy of disseminated candidiasis.

Isoleucine Plays an Important Role for Maintaining Immune Function
Changsong Gu 1 2, Xiangbing Mao 1 2, Daiwen Chen 1 2, Bing Yu 1 2, Qing Yang 3
Affiliations expand
PMID: 30843485 DOI: 10.2174/1389203720666190305163135
Abstract
Branched chain amino acids are the essential nutrients for humans and many animals. As functional amino acids, they play important roles in physiological functions, including immune functions. Isoleucine, as one of the branched chain amino acids, is also critical in physiological functions of the whole body, such as growth, immunity, protein metabolism, fatty acid metabolism and glucose transportation. Isoleucine can improve the immune system, including immune organs, cells and reactive substances. Recent studies have also shown that isoleucine may induce the expression of host defense peptides (i.e., β-defensins) that can regulate host innate and adaptive immunity. In addition, isoleucine administration can restore the effect of some pathogens on the health of humans and animals via increasing the expression of β-defensins. Therefore, the present review will emphatically discuss the effect of isoleucine on immunity while summarizing the relationship between branched chain amino acids and immune functions.

Branching Out: Alterations in Bacterial Physiology and Virulence Due to Branched-Chain Amino Acid Deprivation
Julienne C. Kaisera and David E. Heinrichscorresponding authora
Danielle A. Garsin, Editor
Danielle A. Garsin, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston;
Author information Copyright and License information Disclaimer
Go to:
ABSTRACT
The branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs [Ile, Leu, and Val]) represent important nutrients in bacterial physiology, with roles that range from supporting protein synthesis to signaling and fine-tuning the adaptation to amino acid starvation. In some pathogenic bacteria, the adaptation to amino acid starvation includes induction of virulence gene expression: thus, BCAAs support not only proliferation during infection, but also the evasion of host defenses. A body of research has accumulated over the years to describe the multifaceted physiological roles of BCAAs and the mechanisms bacteria use to maintain their intracellular levels. More recent studies have focused on understanding how fluctuations in their intracellular levels impact global regulatory pathways that coordinate the adaptation to nutrient limitation, especially in pathogenic bacteria. In this minireview, we discuss how these studies have refined the individual roles of BCAAs, shed light on how BCAA auxotrophy might promote higher sensitivity to exogenous BCAA levels, and revealed pathogen-specific responses to BCAA deprivation. These advancements improve our understanding of how bacteria meet their nutritional requirements for growth while simultaneously remaining responsive to changes in environmental nutrient availability to promote their survival in a range of environments.

When I was like 12 or 13, we had a 'camp out' in a friend's back garden for her birthday. Bit of booze going about and some people got wasted but most remained relatively sober. I had a few drinks but was totally compos mentis

Later on at around 1-2 in the morning, several of us were sat in camping chairs outside of the tent, just chatting whilst those who got severely pissed were asleep on the inside of the tent.

About 5-6 times at random intervals, there were these all encompassing flashes of light. Very brief lasting probably a quarter of a second each, no particular pattern to them. Happened over the course of maybe 10 minutes or so. They seemed to be coming from the sky, no obvious source. When I say all encompassing, I mean that in the sense that it was literally flash that illuminated everything, whited out your vision for that brief period.

We all saw it, never worked out what it was. Clear skies, no thunder. No idea what it could have been but was weird as fuck

>Just finish a long ass shift at a restaurant I used to work at. It was around the holidays and we were fairly busy.
>We're closed and I'm in the backroom alone getting my stuff together before I leave.
>Putting on a heavy jacket since I walk to work and it's dark and snowing outside.
>There are about 3 or 4 other people closing up with me, so I'm not completely alone or anything. Not really important to the story but just some context.
>As I'm collecting my things there's still music playing over the speakers throughout the restaurant.
>At this point I'm tired but I was used to my hours and felt completely fine and normal.
>Downtown by Petula Clark starts playing.
>Have never listened to this song before, but I felt a wave of uneasiness the second it started to play.
>Instantly feel lightheaded and numb, I stumble backwards and almost fall down, catching myself on a shelf.
>Sit on the floor and feel very weird and paranoid, have never felt this way before. It was what I imagine a panic attack would feel like, I guess.
>I sit and breathe until the song stops, that's when I get myself up and I instantly start feeling better.
>I have no history of fainting or anything of the sort.
That wasn't the weird part though.
>Like two days later.
>Guy in Nashville detonates a car bomb, before exploding he was playing sounds on a speaker.
>He was also playing Downtown by Petula Clark.
>Probably a massive coincidence, but it's still very weird. I have never reacted that way in regard to anything before or since.
>Also, we were a "sportsy" bar place, why did we have some old ass slow 60s song playing? I worked there for over a year and that was the first and last time I ever heard that song play. All our managers (managers were the only ones that could change the music) were in their late 20s or early 30s so it wasn't some boomer playing old music he liked.
>It still confuses me to this day. Hopefully I'm not some sleeper agent that activates to Downtown by Petula Clark.

>Watch it for a while.
>Light performs a sudden and instantaneous ~120 deg turn away from me to the east. As in, more than a right angle turn to the left (from my POV), partially doubling back on its original direction of travel.
>No change in speed, only direction.
>I watch it move eastwards until I lose sight of it. It performs no further odd movements, returning to looking exactly like a satellite.
>Thats it. No idea what it was, have never seen anything like it since, and still have no good explanation.

I will share two stories. Both can be rationally explained, they’re aren’t extraordinary, but I felt like that character in Mulholland Drive (at the diner) who sees the hidden madness behind things.

#1 After divorcing my father, my mother and my siblings lived near the end of a cul-de-sac in a small English town. At the time, I was five or six. It was a Sunday night, and for whatever reason I slept in the same bed as my mother. We both woke around three, and rushed to the window. A man, followed by a helicopter search light was rushing from the end of our cul-de-sac, accessible by a footpath, and up our street. In a flash, he was surrounded by armed police(?) officers dressed in all black. My mother then dragged me away from the window and I quickly fell back into sleep. To this day, she affirms this happened and remembers only as much detail as I do. This was peculiar because it was so out of place for a sleepy town, and that I recall everything happening in complete silence. I can still recall the black silhouettes surrounding the man, and the search light. But not the man or the sounds.

#2 next.

When I was a kid my mom, my dad, and I were driving home late at night and saw a searchlight beaming down on the woods a quarter mile from our house. We thought we could see people walking between the trees but it was too far away to be sure. My dad was driving and he just raced out of there while my mom and I tried to see where the light was coming from. There was nothing in the news about a search, we never actually saw where the light was coming from, and we never heard anything (if it was a helicopter that low and that close how would we not hear something?).
I live near a big airbase so a lot of “UFO” stuff I just chalk up to aircraft I’m not supposed to know about but a silent invisible search vehicle looking for people in the woods is still something my family talks about from time to time.

>what position should my neck\ head be in? chin touching the chest area?
Neck in a natural position, in line with the spine, with the chin tucked in slightly.
Tongue touching the palate lightly, just behind the upper teeth.
>Should I apply the "3 bandha locks" of Hindu yoga? (butt clench,abs clench,throat clench)?
Sure, why not? If it helps you progress go for it.
>and what about inversion asanas? the ancient hindu texts promise immortality to whoever spends 3 hours. a day,for 6 months,doing a head-stand asana.
Careful what you read.
It's possible you can achieve something like immortality, but not because of the posture itself. The posture acts as a vehicle for the energy cultivated in meditation to be directed and trained in certain ways.
If you want to try it and experiment, go for it. Just don't get caught up thinking it's the pose itself, the pose is a vehicle for the energy to be developed in certain ways. It's a tool to enhance the meditation and reap particular benefits from it.
That said, why not try it? Worst you can do is keep your body healthy and happy, and best case scenario you become an immortal hermit living in caves meditating and lifting.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34045426
Qi Gong and Tai chi are maybe the best examples of this, as well as corruption of understanding.
Alot of people look at these and go 'das bull shite' because charlatans promote the practices for those as a means to an end in of themselves.
But these in particular were meant to develop the energy at an incredibly subtle level, when spiritual illiteracy took over people had no clue how to use these. They reduced it down to a kind of dance.
All of these practices in northern-eastern asia (IE; japan, Korea, China) root back to bodhidharma's transmission. How legitimate that is can be questioned, but it illuminates their purpose from the very beginning. It was always meant to be secondary to the meditation, never the practice in of itself.
If you don't understand meditation, you're not gonna get anything out of these beyond maybe some physical health benefits. It's more apparent with these systems in particular because they were developed with the meditation energy (life force/prana/qi/vriya/piti/whatever) as the main focus as the tool to repair and change the body. It was made for someone who already is cultivating their meditation.
Compared this to normal hindu-buddhist yoga, which cultivates the body to prepare for the meditation and enhance it, instead of the other way around.

I agree, people who always search for the "right" method or the "right" starting point never stick with one method long enough to see results and they get frustrated.
Directing your focus/your awareness, that's what meditation is, for me it was directing it towards the feeling of my body and the sensations of it, I disliked watching my breath or my thoughts, I focused on the body because that's what felt correct for me. Others say that feeling the body is advanced energy work but for me it was already there since day one, maybe me being a longtime athlete helped by giving me a proprioception sense better than the average human.

After I focused long enough I got to the point that expanding that awareness was easier, then I could focus on my breath or on my thoughts easier, however I decided to expand into other stuff, that stuff could better described as "feelings of my being" which corresponded to some trauma and anxieties I carried within me since childhood, after staying with them long enough I managed to ease the feelings to the point that I became free from them.

So yeah, just find your own path, take advice from everything in life but realize that it's you and only you the one who will take you to where you want to go.

>>34035925
I don't believe you first off, but your bullshit aside, you can improve strength through certain types of meditation. Muscle hypertrophy is the process of strengthening muscle through repeated stress, causing the fibers to tear and heal, becoming stronger and larger. This is what most people do to train strength in the gym. There is another way, however. This is called Neural Adaptation; training your brain and nervous system to utilize muscle more efficiently and effectively.
Whether you define these techniques as meditation is up to you. I want you to stand up and place your arms in front of you. Tighten your core and flex your arms without moving your hands. As hard as you can. Flex until you can feel every muscle in your arm straining. Try to maintain that flex and move to the next step.
While keeping your core tight, reach forward as if you were grabbing onto a ball. Without relaxing your arms, pull them back, as if placing the ball onto a table beside you. Reach forward again and repeat the motion. Keep your arms flexed, your core muscles tight, and breath steadily. Over time your brain will learn more efficient neural pathways to the muscles fibers, allowing you to activate specific muscle groups more effectively. This will not enable you some magical strength, but it will unlock your full potential if done correctly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34045601
This fallacy is called begging the question. You are starting with the assumption that such experiences are hallucinatory.

In fact, evidence has suggested just the opposite. People experiencing NDEs sometimes view their bodies from above, and see things they would not have been able to see from the physical perspective of their unconscious body. Why would they see and know these things if they can’t from their body’s angle, and when they should be unconscious anyway?

And in addition, hallucinations can be generalized as experiences that feel as real or less real than reality. NDEs are almost always described as more real than our reality. And often people compare the reality shift to that which people experience when waking up from a dream. In other words, we know dreams are not real since, when we wake up, it is more realistic than the dream. Similarly, people who experience NDEs are often quoting as describing the reality of NDEs as so realistic that not only is the step between reality and NDE greater than the step between dream and reality, but the NDE reality is impossible to put into human language. This simply is not symptomatic of any hallucination we know.
>but what about drugs?
Yes, with drugs like DMT, people report hallucinations that can seem more real than reality. However, firstly, drug-induced hallucinations differ greatly depending on which drug you are using, but none of them come close to matching all the symptoms of an NDE:
>clarity
>belief that it is not a hallucination
>high sense of reality
>consistency across people’s experience
>consistency across belief systems
>high retention of memory after experience
>ego death
Secondly, drug users also get NDEs, and drug users very consistently say that NDEs are way more intense than any drug experience they have had.

Please note what I am hinting at is firstly true wood-turpentine, not mineral terpentine, which is a different thing.
Secondly, it is used in this example by producing a salve that is applied to open wounds to cause them to grow back. I am unaware of what effect it would have if taken internally, I don't think that would work, there's too many heavy organic molecules produced via combustion and distillation.
tl;dr this salve is highly experimental, and I only know of through old folk-tradition, but in theory I can see how there'd be something to it.
It is to the best of my knowledge produced by combining 1 part real turpentine, 1 part 'stove-pipe soot' (And in this context, what we're talking about is that the people who produced this substance all heated their houses and cooked on wood-stoves, burning the same kind of wood as the terpentine was harvested from, and therefore their stove-pipes would have accidentally worked as a sort of crude fractional-still, yielding a great variety of useful organic compounds.), and one part ash from the fires of this process. (I hypothesize that the ash was used to change the PH of the salve, or perhaps served some nano-structural function, but I don't really know.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34042094
>NDEs are real
Near Death Experiences are just that, experiences. The only way to determine whether an experience is real or not is 1) does it have real world effects 2) can those effects be measured? If I tell you I saw a unicorn, that just means I have a story of a unicorn. It doesn't mean I actually saw a flesh and blood unicorn. I would need to provide a flesh and blood unicorn that could be measured and weighed as any other organism to prove it is real. Likewise, the experience of dreaming isn't real, because peoples' brainwaves can be measured and a scientist can determine when a person is asleep by those measurements, and when people are woken up from deep REM sleep they all report seeing and hearing things. Dreams themselves are not real because no one in the room can observe or measure what exists within the dream.

NDEs are not real experiences because people who are not dead cannot observe or measure anything that happens during a NDE. Therefore, either science is not a valid method or NDEs are not real.

I can appreciate the dedication some people have to NDEs. I have had countless dreams, vivid, intense, catastrophic, blissful, etc. I've often times found myself wondering if my dreams are real, but no matter how much I wish they were I have to admit I can't prove it to anyone else. I have no choice but to conclude that NDEs are nothing more than especially intense dreams that happen when a person's body and brain are under an enormous amount of stress. They are profound, they are mystical, but they are dreams. To tell people they shouldn't fear death because they might have a nice dream is absurd.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34076364
Edwin Hubble noticed that light coming from all of the galaxies around us shifts toward the red end of the spectrum. This can be interpreted as a Doppler effect of the galaxies all moving away from us. This was Hubble’s interpretation, and it is the commonly accepted interpretation now. The most natural conclusion to draw from this is that we are at the center of the universe. As Hubble writes, “Such a condition would imply that we occupy a unique position in the universe, analogous, in a sense, to the ancient conception of a central earth” (The Observational Approach to Cosmology 40). Hawking agrees that this is the most natural explanation of the observation: “Now at first sight,” he writes, “all this evidence that the universe looks the same whichever direction we look in might seem to suggest there is something special about our place in the universe. In particular, it might seem that if we observe all other galaxies to be moving away from us, then we must be at the center of the universe” (A Brief History of Time 44-45).

So both admit that this is the most natural interpretation of the evidence. That puts the burden of proof on anyone claiming otherwise. Nevertheless, both Hawking and Hubble admit that they reject this most natural interpretation without being able to shift the burden. They do not even try. Indeed, they do not even pretend to try. Hubble calls the principle on which his alternative explanation rests “sheer assumption” (Observational Approach to Cosmology 42), and he admits that the hypothesis that we are at the center of the universe “cannot be disproved…” (Observational Approach to Cosmology 40). In other words, he admits that the burden of proof cannot be shifted. Hawking agrees, saying, “We have no scientific evidence for, or against, this assumption [the assumption that the universe has no center]” (A Brief History of Time 45).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34076364
Hubble’s justification for rejecting the geocentric interpretation is sheer horror of its implications. He admits that he does it “to escape the horror of a unique position (Hubble 46 ), a conclusion that “must be avoided at all costs” (40).

Hawking rejects the geocentric conclusion simply because it is too weird: “We believe it [the alternative view] on the grounds of modesty. It would be most remarkable if the universe looked the same in every direction around us, but not around other points in the universe!” (A Brief History of Time 45).

The alternative view they are referring to is “Friedmann’s second assumption,” and it explains the observed phenomenon by claiming that there is no center to the universe. The usual analogy is to imagine a balloon with dots on it. The surface of the balloon represents all of space, and the dots represent galaxies. In that scenario, no matter which dot you are, all the other dots would seem to be leaving you as the balloon expands.
Of course, this requires you to ignore the actual space inside the balloon, the expansion of which explains what is happening on the surface. Nevertheless, this counter-intuitive, impossible to imagine, and scientifically baseless explanation is commonly accepted as the proper way to interpret the red shifting of galactic light.

"...a formulated, definite wish or thought instantly shapes subtle matter, moulding it into an independent being. This mental form lasts as long as the power given to the original thought or wish allows it to. The thoughts of many people are indecisive and evanescent, so that thought forms created by them do not last longer than some minutes or maybe hours. However, a powerful wish or an often-repeated wish or thought can give rise to a mental form lasting for days.

These thought-forms seem to have an instinct or tendency to preserve themselves as all living beings do have. People’s thoughts mostly refer to themselves, so that the thought form will stay with them and, in this way, it will provoke a tendency to repeat the thought or wish from which it was created so as to gain power and prolong its own life. from my limited perspective it is paradoxically both a simple and complex topic.
ill attempt to explain how i understand it, very briefly (so cutting out lots of stuff). first, if you take into account the laws of creation and reality being mostly your creation. then entertain the idea that belief, faith, and imagination kind of work together with each other to manifest/shape/create the reality you perceive.

using that thought with magic, we can observe that there seems to be two 'schools'. one is based on inner magic, or self transformation, expanding awareness of the self etc, while the other is kind of practical, using rituals, trances, wands, chants etc. people may use both, but may have different purposes. all work with belief systems, imagination and faith.

for example briefly looking at practical magic. much of it involves ancient rituals or older rituals. but why? presumably because these rituals are given power, in a sense, both to the imagination of the users, and into the universe itself. when rituals are performed a sort of 'imprint' is left which in itself can be powered or stored with the energy/intent. this is why old orders and secret groups probably carefully hand down rituals so that no one else can use or maybe even abuse them in some way i guess. it may also involve protecting the users.
there is also something you might call, universal 'resonance'. that is, the frequency of the tones and geometry of patterns serves the purpose of invoking an energy, almost like a mathematical formula.

lastly, amplifying the strength of any magic by adopting what is sometimes known as the 'magical personality'. why you might see people dress up or pick special areas to perform some rituals or meditations. this can solidify the belief system. and this done with the intent to separate themselves from the 'everyday' version to kind of step through a portal of the mind. and of course, some areas may also emit a vibration that is beneficial.

the last thing i wanted to say is that you can technically create your own rituals and meditations. you can borrow from others from what you are drawn to or just your own individual. either way there would be someone or some group your probably tapping into anyway (including the higher self).

the upside is that you can attempt to explore and create whatever your imagination and beliefs will allow.
the downside is that it may be much more difficult to ingrain the belief and grow the faith in that your working on your own (assuming you have not requested the assistance or guidance of other beings). this may require much more discipline and work in an area that already requires it.. or not, it depends on many factors of the individual.

you could use existing rituals and meditations with the upside that they are most likely heavily used by others and have been for eons. thus they may have a very strong resonance and require much less 'suspension of disbelief'. the downside would mostly be related to finding accurate works, and researching the correct pronunciations and movements, if using chants or geometric patterns etc. lastly, if you decided to work with or join a group, you might want to be cautious of other peoples intent, and they might just be something that you really not wanting be involved with.

this has been mostly about practical magic as i assume its the thing most people think about when someone mentions the occult and magic. but the inner magic is where much of the 'action' takes place. as the belief systems you hold are like programs running the background 24/7 and are the things that heavily shape your reality so to speak. by expanding your awareness of the self and facing the parts you feel hold you back / are negative / self limiting etc, and transforming these beliefs you directly link into that part of the universe that reflects back your creation to you.. if that makes any sense.

anyway, that is all from me

>darker area, not many street lights
>listening to music
>song ends and there's a pause
>can hear a car but no headlights
>looks around and notices a van behind him about 10 feet away
>van stops
>two guys jump out and start to run towards John
>John freaks the fuck out and sprints
Now keep in mind John is far from an athlete. Skinny fat at best and hasn't ran a day in his life, so his stamina was basically non existent, which led to the next part.
>John realizes these guys are going to catch him
>As he's running he turns the corner and there's a strip mall with a couple shops
>Guys aren't letting up and John knows he can't out run them
>John fucking JUMPS INTO the front glass window of a subway
>is torn the fuck up, legs and arms cut badly from glass
>alarm system goes off
>John turns around and sees the guys running off, most likely spooked by the alarm and possible cameras
>John gets up and stumbles into the back of the store and hides in the bathroom and locks the door
>starts to pass out from the pain if getting shredded by the glass window
>calls 911 and just says "subway, kidnap, bathroom" and passes out
>Wakes up in a hospital
>apparently lost a lot of blood and was lucky not to be dead
>has huge scars on his arms and legs, and is mentally broken
>cops reviewed the footage, didn't see the van because they ran around a corner to get to the strip mall
>did see the two guys faces though

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34069041
What I should say is John was a goofy charismatic guy who constantly looked on the bright side of things. Regardless of a bad situation, he found silver linings and was always optimistic for a better future. But this event damaged him beyond repair. I was friends with John while this all happened, and although you may think he's luckily to be alive, this incident completely shattered his mind. He initially was ok, but after he found out it was human traffickers or some crazy shut like organ harvesters, he shut down. No more optimism, no silver lining or hopeful for the future, he now looked at life through a cynical and doom filled lense. John bought a gun and locked himself inside his house for multiple weeks. We had police do welfare checks on him so we knew he was alive, and everytime he would answer and say he's fine. But he wouldn't talk to his friends, family, job, nothing. Just the cops when they showed up, and there wasn't much else they could do since he hadn't threatened suicide or doing any harm.

After a couple weeks he finally started talking to me, and he told me all of this, and that this whole experience destroyed his mental health and that every time he sees the scars on his bodies he's reminded of the fate he almost met. Cold dead eyes and doesn't laugh or smile, and anytime we hang out and he always keeps his right hand by his side next to his gun. That's the new John. Over the years he's gotten better, doesn't always have his hand on a gun, and occasionally laughs, but he's broken beyond repair.

I'm posting his story to help others understand what this kind of shit does to some people. If you ever have a friend or family member go through something so traumatic, stick with them, as hard as it may be. John said if it wasn't for his friends and family's support he would have killed himself in the two weeks he was in his house.

I am very good at visualising, and always have been stuck in daydreams and carried away by them. It isn't something that takes focus, I automatically visualise in mind's eye, whatever information is fed to me that I'm not directly observing; whether that be a story I am told/hear, a book or a smell/touch. Just as the brain of a non-visual person would "decode" and make sense of whatever information they recieve, I too do the same but also build mental images.
I always found maths hard as I have to visualise the numbers and such, which makes me slower than people who seem to be able to just conceptualise it abstractly.
I have known a few people without a mind's eye, mostly women, and they these traits in common:
>struggled to describe features articulately, relying on fact-like points instead
>they all had weak imaginations and couldn't come up with new ideas easily
>they all read VERY fast as they didn't visualise what is they were reading

Alright, I'll take a try at this. You will need a timer.
Pay attention to your breathing, count outloud how many times you breathe in 30 seconds, then hold your breathe for 30 seconds. After this set a minute long timer and start to count your breathes again, start counting outloud, and then become silent but still keep count of it. Reset the timer start counting outloud again and after 20 seconds tick on timer go silent and still keep count.
Do this twice more so that the last time you reset the timer you are counting silently the whole time.

This should force you to hear your own voice in your head counting.

From Chapter 9 of the Book of Jasher.

23 And all the families assembled consisting of about six hundred thousand men, and they went to seek an extensive piece of ground to build the city and the tower, and they sought in the whole earth and they found none like one valley at the east of the land of Shinar, about two days' walk, and they journeyed there and they dwelt there.

24 And they began to make bricks and burn fires to build the city and the tower that they had imagined to complete.

27 And when they were building they built themselves a great city and a very high and strong tower; and on account of its height the mortar and bricks did not reach the builders in their ascent to it, until those who went up had completed a full year, and after that, they reached to the builders and gave them the mortar and the bricks; thus was it done daily.

28 And behold these ascended and others descended the whole day; and if a brick should fall from their hands and get broken, they would all weep over it, and if a man fell and died, none of them would look at him.

31 And they built the tower and the city, and they did this thing daily until many days and years were elapsed.

37 And they ceased building the city and the tower; therefore he called that place Babel, for there the Lord confounded the Language of the whole earth; behold it was at the east of the land of Shinar.

38 And as to the tower which the sons of men built, the earth opened its mouth and swallowed up one third part thereof, and a fire also descended from heaven and burned another third, and the other third is left to this day, and it is of that part which was aloft, and its circumference is three days' walk.

>>34073036
>>34073056
>If the Greek spelling of Nero Caesar (Neron Kaisar) is transliterated into Hebrew (nrwn qsr), the numerical equivalent is 666—although it should be remembered that this number was not represented as a figure but as letters of the alphabet or written in full. In other words, the "number of the beast" was not expressed as "666" (indeed, discrete Arabic numerals would not be invented for another five hundred years) but by the phrase hexakosioi hexekonta hex or the numerical values of the Greek letters themselves, chi (600), xi (60), and stigma (6).
>But what is curious is not so much that 666 can be decoded to signify Nero but that the name is encoded in this particular number, especially since it could have been represented as readily in other ways. It only is when the words are transliterated from Greek into Hebrew and then calculated that the numeration adds up to 666 (nrwn qsr, 50 + 200 + 6 + 50 + 100 + 60 + 200). Even so, this is an alternate spelling, a letter being transliterated in "Neron" (nrwn instead of nrw) but not in "Caesar" (qsr instead of qysr). Although these forms do appear in the Talmud and an Aramaic scroll from Qumran, they no doubt complicated the solution to the puzzle.
>For Watt, the significance of 666 is that its expression in Latin is the sequential Roman numerals DCLXVI, which parallels but is the antithesis of the "Alpha and Omega" that John used to characterize both Christ (22:13) and God (1:8, 21:6). As the Deity represents the beginning and end, so the Antichrist is a reversal of the first and last, D (500) preceding I (1). To phrase this another way, 666 (or rather DCLXVI) signifies the Antichrist because that number signifies Nero, and Nero—who was a matricide, proclaimed his divinity on coins as the "Savior and Benefactor of the World," and was the first emperor to persecute Christians—signifies the Antichrist.
https://penelope.uchicago.edu/~grout/encyclopaedia_romana/gladiators/nero.html

This happened to me when I was in college a long time ago. Still the weirdest thing to happen to me by far.
>Driving from U of Oregon in Eugene back home to Boise for fall break
>get started late, by the time I hit central Oregon it’s dark
>for those not familiar with the area, once you get east of the Cascades, it starts to get real isolated real fucking quick
>driving on 2 lane highway through the dark when I hit something in the road
>probably some shit that fell off someone’s truck
>engine starts making weird noises and check engine light comes on
>FUCK
>start looking for place to pull off and try to find a mechanic
>pull onto this farm to market road
>drive about a mile and see a farm supply store with the lights still on
>couple locals sitting outside, drinking and smoking
>I get out and try to introduce myself, but they’re acting bizarre as fuck
>start losing their shit over how nice my car is and how they never see anything like it out there
>…my car is some rusted piece of shit imported from god knows where
>next they start talking about how amazing my shoes are
>my broke ass literally bought these shoes from some tweaker in downtown Portland after my old ones gave out
>creeped out by these guys, decide to go inside
>kind looking old dude at the counter
>when he sees me walk in, he starts ranting incomprehensibly about some numbers that grow in the soil (?)
>wtf is this place
>look around the shop, pretty typical looking country store
>look in one of the seed bins
>it’s filled with fucking gummy bears
>alright fuck this
>rush out of there, decide to take my chances with the car
I’ve driven down that road multiple times since, but I’ve never been able to find that weird fucking gummy bear store again. I try not to think about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34033077
119 is probably the strongest.
>This psalm is one of about a dozen alphabetic acrostic poems in the Bible. Its 176 verses are divided into twenty-two stanzas, one stanza for each letter of the Hebrew alphabet; within each stanza, each of the eight verses begins (in Hebrew) with that letter.[13] The name of God (Yahweh/Jehovah) appears twenty-four times.
>The acrostic form and the use of the Torah words constitute the framework for an elaborate prayer. The grounds for the prayer are established in the first two stanzas (alef and beth): the Torah is held up as a source of blessing and right conduct, and the psalmist pledges to dedicate himself to the law. The prayer proper begins in the third stanza (gimel, v. 17). Like many other psalms, this prayer includes dramatic lament (e.g. verses 81–88), joyous praise (e.g. verses 45–48) and prayers for life, deliverance and vindication (e.g. verses 132–34). What makes Psalm 119 unique is the way that these requests are continually and explicitly grounded in the gift of the Torah and the psalmist's loyalty to it.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psalm_119

It's very simple. When you do the Psalm Magic formula with EVERY Psalm (set a desire, read the Psalm out loud once as an incantation, then read through it again to find the occult meanings), then that's one degree of initiation. Doing it again counts as another degree, and so on. You don't have to do the Psalms in order. Don't forget that Psalm 119 is broken up into multiple Psalms.

Not recommended to rush the process, since the wisdom comes from deciphering the meanings of each Psalm. If you feel like a Psalm's calling you to go over it multiple days, do so.

Source: Ariel Gatoga and Pater Amadeus mention these in their booklets.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34015108
>>34015413
>God promised to give back 10x (tithe means ten) whatever's offered to Him
horrendously false. Tithe means tenTH, as in you are to give a tenth of your income (money but also produce itself as most people in history did not have income in money). The tithe was not a generous gift but required in the Mosaic law, it was to sustain the Levites and priesthood and for maintenance of the temple. This was how they stayed alive as they were not given any land inheritance in Canaan, the tithe was God's provision for them.
There is Scripture that says if you give (freely, so not as part of the tithe) to someone who you do not expect to be able to pay you back, God will repay you. But the implication there is not that the "repayment" will be a literal monetary gift or any specific concrete blessing. Rather it is that you aren't simply throwing away resources, God sees what you did as an act of kindness and obedience to His Word and He will not forget.

God owes you nothing and He never will. Any blessing you have received He gave you because of His immeasurable grace.

>>34052695
>to be fair the whole bible is "trust me bro". I'm still undecided whether or not paul was a false prophet tho.
Paul literally says "don't trust me bro".

Romans 3:7 (KJV)
For if the truth of God hath more abounded through my lie unto his glory; why yet am I also judged as a sinner?

Later translations try to cover up for Paul, saying that he was hypothetically speaking for someone else (like the NIV translation for example). However, it's clear that he's talking about himself, because he directly misquotes the Bible multiple times.

Isaiah 28:16
Therefore thus saith the Lord God, Behold, I lay in Zion for a foundation a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation: he that believeth shall not make haste.

Paul twists the quote like so:
Romans 9:33
As it is written, Behold, I lay in Sion a stumblingstone and rock of offence: and whosoever believeth on him shall not be ashamed.

Deuteronomy 30:14
But the word is very nigh unto thee, in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that thou mayest do it.

And again Paul changes the meaning to suit his teachings.
Romans 10:8
But what saith it? The word is nigh thee, even in thy mouth, and in thy heart: that is, the word of faith, which we preach;

The former clearly says "that thou mayest do it", as in, to uphold the law through your actions, in direct opposition to Paul's "you just need faith bro".

In other words, Paul misleads "Christians" like >>34046788 that thought that what Jesus said to do was too hard.

Not from shifting.

>hyper advanced
We only describe them as advanced because we don't understand how they work yet. Some of the interesting anecdotes from the 1940s seems to implicate electromagnetic effects as a weakness for these phenomena. Roswell and Trinity crashes are a bit too on the nose with nuclear research to be coincidence, and there are persistent rumors that a modified form of radar was/is capable of "turning off" the special characteristics of the craft and turning them into bricks.
But of course, then you get into the more esoteric parts of the field. Are these things even alien, or are they living alongside us? Could they be another civilization of humans, or close relatives, whose technological development took a wildly different path from ours? Spiritual sciences, alchemy. Or perhaps even stranger sorts of things that defy our understanding of what is real. What if these craft are "made vulnerable" because that is their narrative purpose and it is their recovery and study which are the end goal of a phenomenon "gifting" us these objects?

But it does seem odd that one minute they can hover over nuclear silos and play with the missile control systems as they see fit, then the next some junk rocket catches them off guard.

I think there are two distinct possibilities. First would be that all parties involved, even ourselves, are involved in a secret struggle of factions who have decided that mutual suppression is the most beneficial state for their control over the game pieces. But even those things are essentially "in dispute" as to what is real. In a certain sense, the paranormal may be bound to its secrecy at a conceptual level such that it is always at the edge of our awareness both as individuals having liminal encounters and as a collective culture trying to comprehend the subject. Circumstances will always conspire to make ultimate proof impossibly elusive. The best videos, which will be rare, will be exciting but too mysterious to prove anything. The best pictures are so stunning that they MUST be fake, because otherwise we have all stared directly at proof, right? It's the same for witness reports with corroboration through multiple witnesses, physical trace evidence, and all that stuff that makes a report credible. We already have mountains of it. It's a no brainer if you actually start researching the subject. So how does skepticism hold any power in society?
I suppose the third possibility is that they already have, many times, and no one seems to care. There is a massive literature of "aliens came down in a ship and we interacted, then they left" reports which suggests that they regularly reveal themselves. Combine this with all the reports of other ways in which people report experiencing contact with "the other."
